subject: Climbing Liberty
event: I climbed to the crown of the Statue of Liberty once. Once was enough, believe me. The interior of the statue is stifling and hot, the winding metal steps are narrow and steep, and you're in a long line of people, with someone on the step ahead of you and someone on the step behind. And once you reached the top, well, the inside of Lady Liberty's head is pretty cramped as well, and the windows are thick and pitted and do not actually offer that great a view. It's not an experience I am eager to repeat... Nonetheless, I am glad I did it, and I want others to have the chance to do it too. Which is why I was heartened today by the announcement that the Obama administration is once again opening Lady Liberty to visitors. George W. Bush had, of course, closed the monument after 9/11 (visitors were still allowed on Liberty Island and could tour the museum in the statue's base, but were not allowed inside the lady herself), citing possible terrorist attacks as the reason. Was that a danger? To some extent, sure. I have no doubt that Osama bin Laden would love to destroy the Statue of Liberty. But closing the statue was not the answer. It was, in fact, an act of cowardice, "letting the terrorists win." Being able to climb up inside the Statue of Liberty is not, of course, a fundamental right like freedom of speech or freedom of religion... but it was something cool that many generations of Americans had been able to enjoy, and having it taken away "to keep us safe" always galled me. And now it's back. Hurrah, hurrah. My mother, a child of another era, first visited Lady Liberty at a time when tourists were still allowed to climb up into her torch. Now THAT would be cool. Unlike the crown, the torch is open air, so the views would be spectacular. But the torch was closed to the public long before I first got to Liberty Island in the 50s. These days, I understand, no one goes up there but Superman... and the park rangers stationed at the monument, who rumor tells us like to climb up there to make out.

comments.article:
I climbed to the crown once, too. I hated it. Those helical stairs -- and the plunge on either side -- were really panic-inducing.

But I agree; it ought to be there for those who wish to make the climb.

You know, I blinked the first time I saw this blog and noted you were supporting the Sansa Stark Candidate, but nah, political differences aside, it's actually pretty awesome that George R.R. Martin believes the modern age is worth being optimistic about. And now I don't think it's any coincidence that Dany, who actually manages to accomplish things worth accomplishing, is also one of the precious few characters with a truly forward outlook... :D

I think climbing the Statue of Liberty is very symbolic. Not only because it's such an American icon, but also because it's very hard, and you kind of get to feel first-hand the difficulty of attaining freedom (or something cheesy like that). I'm glad they've opened it up again. I haven't ever been, myself, but it's on the list.

Hehe. Since I'm from Toronto, I guess the equivalent here is climbing the CN Tower. I really don't think I have the guts for that yet. And, if I'm not mistaken, it's not open to the public. It's a once-a-year event for charity, where you sign up with teams and sponsors and all that. It would be cool to do that sometime. :)

actually it is open to the public, but most people take the elevator.  Definitely recommend it. Been up there a couple of times.  Also for the charity event you don't NEED a team or even sponsors, its the same as all the heart and stroke things we did as kids in the area.

I've never been, and I have to admit, I'm somewhat ambivalent on the idea of going to New York City. Granted, this is severely colored by the fact that my friends who have moved up there have become absolute twatbags, and part of me knows that my mental self would start investigating to find out why.

Still, I concur with you that closing it to tourists was an absolute act of cowardice. So much of what happened in response to 9/11 was absolutely disappointing, from the pop-up patriots (as I called them), to the ludicrous 'security' measures, to the blatant disregard for the Constitution.

All of these things made me less than proud to be an American, and even less proud of serving in the Armed Forces; my emigration from the States to the United Kingdom was an easy choice to make (that, and it was the practical choice of countries due to job-getting issues). But hearing of the restoration of various things, of America's dignity and pride... well, it does bring a tear to my eye, and reminds me why I once believed in America is an idea, as a nation.

I think that all makes sense - it's nearing 2am, and I'm dealing with the consequences of downing a liter of delicious V8 in under 10 minutes. Hint - pregnant guts are very irate at me.

>made me less proud to be an American

Why were you proud of being an American in the first place? You should be proud of something you've accomplished or something you created, not something that happens by accident of birth. Being American isn't a SKILL - I see no reason why you should be proud of being American. Glad to be American sounds right.

I remember doing it in the early 60s and having it utterly exhaust me. I can't imagine how I would do it now.

As a side note, there was a news item about you on the Sirius Radio Book channel. I was just thrilled. For a few seconds, I got to live in my ideal world, where the doings of science fiction writers make the news.

I made the trek from the bottom of the base to the top of the Crown when I was 10. I felt a great deal of pride at the time in "proving" myself (and especially in not having needed to take the elevator).

And now that I am, perhaps, in slightly worse shape, I can claim that I have done it once and don't need to "prove" myself again. :)

I, too, have climbed to the crown of the Statue of Liberty. And when you look out those small, dirty windows in her forehead, you suddenly remember that the Statue of Liberty faces out to sea and there is accordingly nothing to look at.

These days, I understand, no one goes up there but Superman

And the X-Men.
Bush thought Magneto was hiding in her.

Except for the four years that I was in the Air Force and the one that I lived in Cali I've lived in NYC since '75 and I've never gone inside Lady Liberty. The lines were too long and the days too hot.

There's really no good reason to either go to the island or climb up inside other than to say that you did. Taking the Staten Island Ferry gives an excellent view of the harbor and Lady Liberty. The Circle Line tour is great as is the Beast boat ride down at the South Street Seaport.

If you have people who've come through Ellis Island that's a better visit.

*sigh* Only times I've been to NY (and anticipate being there for the foreseeable future) were while it was closed. But I'm happy I may have the opportunity in the future!

Thanks for sharing. :)

I went up in the statue when I was in middle school.  When we hit the spiral staircase part, I started having a panic attack, and it continued until we were back down. Also, it was storming like crazy, and when we got to the top, the statue was SWAYING from side to side.  I've never had a panic attack before or after that.  I think my kids will have to go on their own if they want to enjoy that experience :-)

Recent history is a nightmare from which we are slowly waking. I remember when, right before the war, Popular Photography showed a sign at one of the scenic views next to the Golden Gate Bridge saying no photographs could be taken:

Restrictions against what photographers can photograph continue to tighten: now it's bridges. Shoot the Verrazano Narrows Bridge in New York and you might spend a night in the slammer (or at least have you camera or film taken away). How about that most photogenic of spans, the Golden Gate in San Fran? Uh-uh. The California Highway Patrol has recently stopped dozens of photographic offenders in mid-click. While there have been "no pictures" rules in the past, never have they been enforced as vigorously as they are now. "use of camera prohibited; strictly enforced" sign were posted in September on many New York City bridges. It's all about terrorism, of course: nervous police are concerned that some sleeper cell member might photograph structural details for a future attack.


I always wanted to buy a postcard of the bridge taken from that same vantage point and then drive there, hold up the postcard, and take a picture of that. Just to show how absurd the whole thing was.

I think many of these measures weren’t to prevent future attacks, but to prevent reasoned thinking in the public.
Security measures are always unnecessary, except in hindsight of a security failure.
I climbed it from the base to the crown in high school on a field trip from NH.  I climbed it with the guy who became my husband.

The torch was open more recently than that; my father and sister went up it when I was a kid in the 60s (I was too little, and missed my chance.) Maybe it was only open some of the time. I did get to go in the crown, which was very cool, and I do want to go again.

From what I remember, the torch was closed because the arm wasn't designed for the stress of people walking up it every day. Unless I'm mistaken, none of the interior staircases were actually designed for visitors, they were originally intended only for maintenance (though they may have upgraded them before the re-opening.)

YES! When my mother was a child she actually got to walk around the TORCH balcony! That was when it was the old style torch from the 1916 renovation. Totally cool. What _I_ wouldn't want to do is walk down from the dirigible mooring on top of the Empire State bldg. That would be waaay too scary. I totally understand the cramped stairs you describe- The Iowa Capital bldg has a cupola that you can no longer go up into. The stairs are maybe a foot wide, step and curve across inside the dome. I remember climbing them many times as a child. But on crowded days that meant my face was pretty much waiting in line behind somebody's butt. ; S

Us park rangers in the west miss out on all the fun...

Wonderful news, thank you for sharing it! As a lifelong New Yorker who's adored Lady Liberty since early childhood, Bush's decision to close her to tourists really upset me. I understood closing all major tourist sites in the days immediately after 9/11, but not permanently.

I was dragged up to the crown when I was about four or five and I remember being tired but not exhausted. And knowing that I was actually inside the crown of my beloved Statue of Liberty made up for it. Of course, who knows how long it would take to haul myself up there now that I no longer have a child's energy?

While I disagree with GRRM's political views (I believe that unions being too strong and using that strength can result in a less successful business, I am much more in favor of the theory of a "lazy fairy" federal government), I really appreciate his thoughts on this.

I agree that it may have been advisable to close certain buildings if there is a reason to believe that there is imminent danger. However, avoiding what you would otherwise do is giving in to the threats of bullies. President Bush surrounded himself with a number of "loyal" advisers and may have been better off with different advice.

I'm not a huge fan of the Jets, but I will be interested to see how they do with Sanchez. Can they let him take his time and grow? Or will they force him into the fire? Their later pick may have been a little pricey for the trade, IMO, but has some potential.
